column4: Can someone pastebin there native unaltered /etc/apt/sources.list?  I have a corrupted file in my midst
passwd is where all the login password, UID, home directories are kept -- you hose that file you can't login
Can someone pastebin there native unaltered /etc/apt/sources.list?  I have a corrupted file in my midst
does apt-get or similar report any errors with the file?
that could be from the server too .. what's the exact error message?  pastebin it
the preferred way is to use -exec .. xargs is usually broken unless all filenames passed to it are quoted properly
What are the parentheses for?
parantheses in regards to the shell or find?
The parentheses in the exec {}
those are curly-braces not parantheses .. find expands that notation to the filename found so it can be passed to the application properly
for example you might want something like this.    find . -exec echo I found {} \;
Do I always this for example if I was passing the output to sed or something?  Couldn't I just do a find . -name "*.mp3" | sed ...........
you could do that - but you must be careful, that construct can break if your filenames have spaces or newlines, etc in them.
this should help you - http://mywiki.wooledge.org/UsingFind
So what would be the correct syntax for use with sed?
erm it gets complicated.    while read -r -d '' line; do sed -e '...' <<< "$line"; done < <(find . -print0)
the link i gave you discusses some pitfalls and how to avoid them
Im reading the page right now, but the last example you gave me -- That's crazy!
well yea, typically for trivial scripts - you wouldn't go through the hassle - but if you want your script to work everywhere and not be prone to errors, you'd have to worry.
That wiki went from basic to extreme really quick!!!
you mean, you're connected to a remote screen session via SSH and want to forward X back to your client?
